refnamediv.refpurpose: convert wiki-formatted text to latex-beamer code

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FILE - the text-file to be processed

refsect1.title: Usage
refsect1.para: usually you want to pipe the output of wiki2beamer into a file:

refsect1.title: Syntax
refsect1.para: Wiki2beamer has it's own wiki-syntax which is described below. Everything that is unknown will be passed through to the LaTeX output (unless inside special environments).

refsect2.title: overall structure
refsect2.para: A wiki2beamer txt file can consist of two sections: the head and the body. The head is optional and is an autotemplate environment. The body contains the content of the document. If the head (autotemplate) is not given, then only the code for the body will be generated and can be included into a manually crafted LaTeX template file.

refsect1.refsect2:
Environments LaTeX knows many environments, some of which are as simple as \begin{center} \end{center}, others are more complicated. To use these in a more wiki-like fashion, use <[name] to open and [name]> (both at the start of a line) to close environments. It will be simply converted to \begin{name} and end{name}.
No parsing is done. The user is responsible for closing any opened environment.
Special Environments
Unlike standard environments, some environment names are recognized by wiki2beamer. These are: nowiki, code, autotemplate and frame. If wiki2beamer detects one of these it will do some advanced parsing, which can even fail with a syntax error. 1. Autotemplate
Autotemplate can be used at the beginning of a beamer .txt file. It will create the required LaTeX headers to compile the content. The basic syntax is:
<[autotemplate] key=value key=value ... [autotemplate]>
key=value pairs are converted to \keyvalue in the output (except special keys). This means, everything after the = is just appended to \key. The usual usage will be like:
<[autotemplate] usepackage=[utf8]{inputenc} [autotemplate]>
which is converted to \usepackage[utf8]{inputenc}. Wiki2beamer uses the following default set of options which you can override:
<[autotemplate] documentclass={beamer} usepackage={listings} usepackage={wasysym} usepackage={graphicx} date={\today} lstdefinestyle={basic}{....} titleframe=True [autotemplate]>
titleframe is a special key that tells wiki2beamer to create a title frame. To set the title, subtitle and author of the presentation use the keys title, subtitle and author. Overriding of the default options works on
per-key level for: documentclass, titleframe per-package level for: usepackage no overriding for: everything else
2. Code
Code-environments can be used to display animated code listings. Their syntax is as follows:
<[code][key=value,...] ... [code]>
<[code] opens the environment, [code]> closes it, everything after <[code] is passed to the LaTeX listings package as options for this listing. Inside the code environment, [ and ] must be escaped as \[ and \]. Things between [ and ] are animations. There are two kinds of animations:
[<slidespec>some code] - show "some code" only on specified slides [[<slidespec>some code][<slidespec>some other code]] - show "some code" on the slides in the first spec, show "some other code" on the slides in the second spec, fill up space on slides without content with spaces
Slide-specs can be of the form:
n - one single frame n n-m - sequence of frames n to m spec,spec,... - combine multiple specs into on (e.g. <1-3,5>)
